Subjective: Body tension, stiff muscles, rapid breathing, and heart palpitations for a few months, worsening to daily for last 2 weeks. Palpitations are regular, fast; occur spontaneously at rest, last ~30 mins, resolve spontaneously. Rapid breathing also occurs at rest, feels like shortness of breath. Symptoms linked to demanding job as a new doctor with long hours and understaffing. Difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about work; sleeps ~6 hours on work nights, feels tired. No chest pain, irregular heartbeat, dizziness, light-headedness, or abdominal complaints. Symptoms not triggered by exertion. Drinks less coffee to manage palpitations. Social: Doctor, lives with other doctors, good support system. Request: Rule out physical cause like anemia; asks about talking to a professional.
Objective: Vitals: BP 120/60, HR 65, SpO2 98%, RR 14. General: Appears calm. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no abnormal sounds. Heart: Normal heart sounds, no murmurs. Abdomen: Exam deferred, no complaints.
Assessment: Stress-related symptoms, likely secondary to work overload. Rule out somatic causes (e.g., anemia, thyroid dysfunction).
Plan: 1. Blood tests: Hemoglobin, thyroid function, liver and kidney function. 2. Referral: Appointment with mental health nurse for support. 3. Advice: Actively schedule relaxation moments; maintain regular sleep schedule; consider contacting occupational health doctor for work adjustments. 4. Follow-up: Check blood results in 2 days via phone or online portal. 5. Safety Netting: Return if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise.
